person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him to refer to the generation of electric current by chemical action.

person_736.name: WilliamClayfield
person_736.description: A Bristol man of science and a colleague of Davy's at the Medical Pneumatic Institution.

person_677.name: HenryClutterbuck
person_677.description: English medical writer especiially on fever.

person_355.name: HenryWarburton
person_355.description: A member of the Animal Chemistry Club, the Chemical Club, and the Geological Society of London, and a sporting friend of Davy's. FRSL.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_726.name: JamesStodart
person_726.description: British surgical instrument maker; experimented on steel with Michael Faraday. FRSL.

person_151.name: Edward CharlesHoward
person_151.description: A brother of the Duke of Norfolk, he became a chemist, discovering the explosive properties of mercury fulminate. FRSL

person_286.name: CharlesRoyce
person_286.description: Assisted Royal Institution lecturers, including Davy, bewteen 1802 and 1808.

place_518.name: Ganges
place_518.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

place_605.name: River Avon
place_605.description: The River Avon in central England flows generally south-westwards and is a major left-bank tributary of the River Severn.

place_914.name: River Severn
place_914.description: At 220 miles long, the longest river in Great Britain.

place_138.name: Glenarm
place_138.description: Glenarm, a village and castle in County Antrim, Northern Ireland. Davy wrote a poem called 'Glenarm', dated August 1806.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_1392.name: Cyprus
place_1392.description: Cyprus is the third largest and third-most populous island in the Mediterranean. It is east of Greece, north of Egypt, south of Turkey, and west of Lebanon and Syria. Cyprus occupies an important role in Greek mythology, being the birthplace of Aphrodite and Adonis, and home to King Cinyras, Teucer and Pygmalion.

place_070.name: Mucrish
place_070.description: Muckish, one of the Derryveagh Mountains. See the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

place_064.name: Arakil
place_064.description: Arokil is the Errigal mountain of the same range; the handwriting on page 69 in notebook 15B was reproduced by John Davy along with the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

place_430.name: Chimboraco
place_430.description: Now spelled Chimborazo. An inactive stratovolcano situated in the Cordillera Occidental range of the Andes in Ecuador.

place_001.name: Cotopaxi
place_001.description: Cotopaxi is an active stratovolcano in the Andes Mountains, in Ecuador. The first European to climb it was Alexander Von Humboldt in 1802.

place_003.name: Quito
place_003.description: Quito, Ecuador's capital, sits high in the Andean foothills at an altitude of 2,850m. It is constructed on the foundations of an ancient Incan city.
